message.content:
Research and provide comprehensive architectural recommendations for building a Premiere Pro CEP (Common Extensibility Platform) plugin. Focus on:

1. **Project Structure**: Optimal folder layout for CEP panels (manifest.xml, jsx/, js/, css/, CSXS/, etc.)
2. **CSInterface Integration**: Best practices for CSInterface.js usage, event handling, and communication between panel and host
3. **ExtendScript Layer**: How to structure JSX files for Premiere Pro scripting (importing files to project, adding to timeline, etc.)
4. **Build System**: Recommended toolchain (webpack, vite, rollup) for bundling CEP panels with modern frameworks
5. **Debug Configuration**: .debug file setup, remote debugging with Chrome DevTools
6. **Signing & Distribution**: ZXP packaging, certificate signing, installation methods
7. **Version Compatibility**: Handling different Premiere Pro versions and CEP versions

Based on GitHub patterns found:
- Adobe-CEP/Samples PProPanel uses CSInterface v10
- bodymovin extension shows Redux integration with CEP
- evalScript pattern for JS-to-JSX communication

Provide modular, production-ready recommendations with clear separation of concerns.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro ExtendScript API documentation:

## Main Documentation Resources

### Official ExtendScript Documentation
Premiere Pro's ExtendScript-based API allows for broad control of the entire application. ExtendScript can access and manipulate most project elements, including metadata, exporting and rendering options.

The primary documentation is available at **[ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)** - this is the community-maintained Premiere Pro Scripting Guide.

### Important Update: Transition to UXP
As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so, through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered, once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

### Development Environment
ExtendScript Toolkit was deprecated many years ago. Per the PProPanel readme, Microsoft Visual Studio Code + the ExtendScript Debugger extension are the supported development environment.

### Key Differences: ExtendScript vs UXP
An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous. This means they blocked the Premiere UI while they were executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous, and does not block the UI thread.

### Sample Code & Resources
- The PProPanel sample exercises Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/Samples/tree/master/PProPanel.
- PPro ExtendScript is triggered from within (JavaScript-based) CEP panels, like the PProPanel sample.

### New UXP API Documentation
For the newer UXP-based API, Adobe provides official documentation at **[developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/)**.

If you're starting new development, it's worth considering the UXP platform since ExtendScript support is planned only through September 2026.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about CSInterface.js and CEP 12 for Adobe extension development:

## CSInterface.js for CEP 12

For developing CEP 12.0 HTML/JavaScript extensions for Creative Cloud host applications, Adobe provides documentation and APIs.

### Key Resources

The CEP 12 APIs include CSInterface.js and Vulcan.js, which you should include in your extension project if you need to use the APIs.(no content)However, CEPEngine_extensions.js should NOT be included in your extension project as it is already integrated into CEP.

### Where to Get CSInterface.js

You need to download the latest version of CEP's CSInterface.js library, which enables you to control the extension and communicate with the application. The official source is the **Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources** GitHub repository:
- https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources

### Project Structure

You must include a /CSXS/manifest.xml at the root of your project for Adobe apps to register your extension. You probably also want the CSInterface.js library somewhere in your code base to interact with the host app.(no content)One recommended way to structure folders is: /CSXS contains the manifest.xml file which stores extension configuration data (this is a requirement for your extension to show up in the host app), and /client contains the front-end HTML, JavaScript, and CSS code, as well as the required Adobe CSInterface.js library.

### What CSInterface.js Does

CSInterface is the entry point to the CEP extensibility infrastructure. You instantiate this object and use it to access information about the host application in which an extension is running.

Key methods include:
- Your CSInterface instance gives you access to methods and properties useful for building your extension. One of those methods, evalScript(), lets you communicate from your client-side JavaScript to your ExtendScript code and back.

### Additional Documentation

The CEP 12 HTML Extension Cookbook is a great resource provided by Adobe for understanding extension development. You can find it at:
- https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/blob/master/CEP_12.x/Documentation/

### Modern Development Options

BOLT is a boilerplate for building CEP extensions in React, Vue or Svelte, built on TypeScript + Sass - this is a popular modern framework option for CEP development.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe CEP Premiere Pro plugin development for 2024-2025:

## Key Updates for 2024-2025

### Important Transition: CEP to UXP

The official documentation was last updated November 2025, to coincide with the Premiere Pro 25.6 release, also known as "Premiere Pro 2025". As of Premiere Pro 25.6, CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility.(no content)If you are starting new development, Adobe recommends starting in UXP. CEP extensions continue to be supported; the plan is to support both CEP and UXP for a calendar year, after which Adobe will remove support for CEP extensibility.

### CEP 12 - The Final Major CEP Version

CEP 12 shipped with Photoshop 25.12, Premiere Pro 25.0, and After Effects 25.0. InDesign and Illustrator will come later. CEP 12 will be the last major update to CEP, although critical security issues will continue to be addressed. There are no new features planned further.(no content)CEP 12 now supports a newer version of Chromium 99, updated v8 to 9.9.115, and updated the deprecated OpenGL APIs to Metal on Mac.

## Official Resources

### For UXP Development (Recommended for New Projects)
UXP samples are available at https://github.com/AdobeDocs/uxp-premiere-pro-samples/tree/main. Documentation is at https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/. There's also a Premiere Pro UXP Developer Forum at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105.

### For CEP Development (Legacy)
- Code samples for CEP extensions are available at the Adobe-CEP/Samples GitHub repository.
- The PProPanel sample is the right starting point. PPro's ExtendScript API docs are also available.
- CEP 12 documentation is available at: https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/blob/master/CEP_12.x/Documentation/

### How CEP Works
While the JavaScript layer of CEP is up-to-date and flexible to use, when it comes to communicating with the host application, ExtendScript is still needed. In order for CEP Extensions to get information or send commands to the host application, such as After Effects or Premiere Pro, they must call functions in the ExtendScript layer. ExtendScript is Adobe's custom flavor of JavaScript, which is based off of the much older ES3 version of JavaScript (released in 1999).

## Recommendation

If you're wondering whether CEP is still the best approach or if UXP has improved enough to be a viable alternative - if UXP already supports what you're trying to do (or is close), Adobe definitely recommends using UXP.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about CEP extension development with modern build systems like Webpack and Vite in 2024:

## Key Findings

### Bolt CEP - The Leading Modern Solution

Bolt CEP is "a lightning-fast boilerplate for building Adobe CEP Extensions in Svelte, React, or Vue built on Vite + TypeScript + Sass."(no content)It allows you to write Modern ES6 in both the JavaScript and ExtendScript layers, choose Svelte, React, or Vue for your frontend framework, and provides type-safe ExtendScript with Types-for-Adobe. It also offers easy configuration in cep.config.ts, setup for single or multi-panel extensions, optimized build size, and easy publish to ZXP for distribution.(no content)Adobe CC Apps version 2024 or later are supported on Windows, Mac Intel, and Mac Arm64 (M1-M4) which require special setup.

### Why Vite for CEP Extensions

Having a properly configured bundler allows you to write with modern JavaScript features and compile down to ES3 compatible code, so you can write the modern way and still run your code in Adobe apps. Vite takes a different approach than previous bundlers, handling all dev bundling in esbuild (written in Go) for maximum speed, boasting 10-100x faster than previous JS bundlers.

### Vite CEP Plugin

There's also a dedicated Vite plugin for bundling Adobe CEP Extension panels, intended to be used with the Bolt CEP boilerplate.

### Webpack-Based Alternatives

For Webpack users, create-cep-extension offers a near-zero config approach to creating CEP extensions with Webpack and React, closely matching functionality from Create React App.(no content)However, the maintainers now encourage checking out parcel-cep-plugin as a more maintainable approach with a smaller codebase.(no content)Another option is a React + TypeScript + Webpack boilerplate that provides complete TypeScript types for CSInterface/JSX/DescriptorInfo and optimized eslint config.

### General Build Tool Trends (2024)

A 2024 comparison by Tony Cabaye shows esbuild completing medium-sized production builds in under one second, while Webpack often takes several seconds or even minutes. Kinsta's 2024 review demonstrates similar trends, with Vite delivering faster development-server startup and improved hot module replacement responsiveness than legacy Webpack.(no content)Each bundler excels in specific scenarios—Vite for rapid development, Rollup for libraries, esbuild for CI pipelines, and Webpack for complex enterprise needs. Vite and esbuild deliver the fastest feedback loops.

For Webpack users, create-cep-extension offers a near-zero config approach to creating CEP extensions with Webpack and React, closely matching functionality from Create React App.(no content)However, the maintainers now encourage checking out parcel-cep-plugin as a more maintainable approach with a smaller codebase.(no content)Another option is a React + TypeScript + Webpack boilerplate that provides complete TypeScript types for CSInterface/JSX/DescriptorInfo and optimized eslint config.

### General Build Tool Trends (2024)

A 2024 comparison by Tony Cabaye shows esbuild completing medium-sized production builds in under one second, while Webpack often takes several seconds or even minutes. Kinsta's 2024 review demonstrates similar trends, with Vite delivering faster development-server startup and improved hot module replacement responsiveness than legacy Webpack.(no content)Each bundler excels in specific scenarios—Vite for rapid development, Rollup for libraries, esbuild for CI pipelines, and Webpack for complex enterprise needs. Vite and esbuild deliver the fastest feedback loops.

Here are the search results for Adobe CEP ZXP signing, distribution, certificate, and packaging:

## Overview

After you have successfully built your extension, you should package the extension in the ZXP format and sign the extension with a valid certificate in order to distribute your extension properly.

## ZXPSignCmd Tool

Adobe provides a command-line tool, ZXPSignCmd, that you can use to package and sign extensions. Access the CEP Resources page to download the toolkit for your platform. You can use this tool to create a self-signed certificate, create a signed ZXP package, or verify an existing ZXP package.(no content)There's an updated ZXP Sign Command tool available at version 4.1.3 on GitHub (https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources/tree/master/ZXPSignCMD/4.1.3).

## Certificate Types

There are two types of code-signing certificate: commercial certificates provided by a trusted certificate authority, and self-signed certificates.(no content)Packaged extensions must be signed with a certificate, but a self-signed certificate is fine in most cases.(no content)Free extensions can be self-signed, so there are no costs anywhere for getting started. The repository also supports paid and subscription models, but you'll need a purchased CA cert for those.

## Timestamps

A valid timestamp ensures that the certificate used to sign the extension was valid at the time of signing. For this reason, you should always add a timestamp to the signature when you package and sign your extension. A timestamp has the effect of extending the validity of the digital signature.

## 2024 Known Issue: Cross-Platform Signing Compatibility

The problem: ZXP files signed on macOS are failing when installed and run on Windows machines, and vice versa. On Windows, this may mean that the installed panel appears blank, or only functions as expected with debug mode enabled. Expected Behavior: Historically ZXP files signed by ZXPSignCmd may be installed and used successfully on both macOS and Windows, regardless of which platform they were signed on.

### Workaround
For the time being, the workaround is to sign ZXPs on the platform they are expected to be run on. Sign ZXPs for use with macOS on a macOS machine, and ZXPs intended for Windows on Windows devices.

### Best Practices to Avoid Issues
Delete all .DS_Store and __MACOSX folders/files inside your extension directory/subdirectories. Make sure that you don't have any symlinks inside your folders. Some node modules use symlinks, so it's the best to look for symlinks inside the node_modules folder and get rid of those.(no content)It's important to do this if you're planning on distributing in Adobe's Marketplaces, because the developer portal will reject your ZXP upload. While you're at it, delete any zero byte files, as these are also not allowed.

## Distribution Options

The recommended way of distributing extensions is Adobe's "Add-ons" repository. Distributing them directly works fine too, but is a bit less convenient for the end user.(no content)Be aware, though, that Adobe Add-ons is a curated market (similar to most app stores). Each extension is reviewed (by a person!), and must meet various approval guidelines before becoming available to users.

## Installation Tools

Anastasiy's extension manager is a third-party developed tool that can help you install extensions packaged in .zxp format. Download and install Anastasiy's extension manager and follow the instructions.

## Issue with DigiCert/PKCS#11 Certificates

There's concern that new signing methods won't be usable with ZXPSignCmd unless ZXPSignCmd developers contact DigiCert and collaborate on adding support for DigiCert's SMCTL and/or PKCS11/KSP. Other CAs too. After a couple of hours of experimenting this looks like the case.(no content)There's a GitHub ticket for this now (Issue #550 on Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources) for ZXPSignCmd PKCS#11 support.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's information about setting up remote debugging for Adobe CEP extensions using the .debug file and Chrome DevTools:

## CEP Extension Debugging with Chrome DevTools

### Overview
This guide walks you through the necessary steps to debug client-side code in a CEP extension.(no content)Since HTML panels internally use CEF (Chromium Embedded Framework) for rendering, they are largely equivalent to Chrome and support the standard web stack.

### Step 1: Enable Debug Mode for Unsigned Extensions

First, set the following Adobe preference to prevent your host application (Photoshop, InDesign, etc.) from throwing alerts about unsigned extensions.

**Windows:**
Open regedit > HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Software/Adobe/CSXS.8, then add a new entry PlayerDebugMode of type "string" with the value of "1".

**Mac:**
In the Terminal, type: `defaults write com.adobe.CSXS.8 PlayerDebugMode 1`(no content)You might need to potentially cover 5 to 8 depending on which CSXS version you have.

### Step 2: Create the .debug File

Next, create a .debug file for your extension.(no content)To enable panel debugging, create a file called `.debug` in the root of your extension folder, containing XML. The ID should match the Extension ID in your manifest (not the ExtensionBundleID), while the host name specifies which tool you're testing in.(no content)List the Host IDs for each app your extension supports, with a corresponding port of your choosing for debugging. The full list of host application ports is available in the CEP Cookbook.

### Step 3: Connect with Chrome DevTools

Open Chrome and go to http://localhost:8088/ or whichever port you set in your .debug file.(no content)If your panel is working, you'll see the name of your extension as a link you can click on.(no content)The link will take you to the JavaScript Console within Chromium DevTools. The JavaScript Console is where, among other things, you will see your extension's log and error output.

### Troubleshooting

If your debug console in Chrome appears blank, check the contents of your .debug file: Does your extension ID in the .debug file match what's in manifest.xml? Are you listing the supported host app(s) correctly with the right Host ID(s)? Are you attempting to access localhost on the same port that you have indicated in your debug console?

### Alternative: CEF Client

Debugging the JavaScript Layer (Chromium + Node.js) is accomplished with Chrome Dev Tools. Since the latest version of Chrome doesn't always match the CEP version, Adobe distributes a special build of Chromium for each CEP release to ensure smooth debugging, called the CEF Client.

### Debugging Both Layers

CEP Extension / ES6 == Debugging in Chrome Dev Tools. ExtendScript / ES3 == Debugging in VS Code with Adobe's ExtendScript debugger extension. You can run these both at the same time if you like.

content.content:
# PProPanel CEP Extension - Project Structure

Based on the GitHub repository content, here's the complete folder organization:

## Directory Structure

**Root Level Directories:**
- `.vscode/` — Visual Studio Code configuration files
- `CSXS/` — CEP manifest and extension configuration
- `css/` — Stylesheet resources for the panel UI
- `jsx/` — JSX/JavaScript files for panel logic
- `lib/` — Library dependencies and utilities
- `payloads/` — Sample data and configuration payloads

## Key Files

| File | Purpose |
|------|---------|
| `PProPanel.jsx` | Main JSX component for the panel interface |
| `ext.js` | Extension initialization and setup |
| `index.html` | HTML entry point for the CEP panel |
| `.debug` | Debug configuration settings |
| `ReadMe.md` | Project documentation |

## Context

The repository states that "CEP extensions to Premiere Pro have been superseded by UXP Extensibility." As of Premiere Pro 25.6, developers should prioritize UXP for new projects, though CEP "continues to be supported" with planned concurrent support for "a calendar year."

This sample demonstrates "exhaustive exercise of Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API" and serves as a reference for developers working with CEP panel development.

content.content:
# Bolt CEP: Project Structure & Development Workflow

## Project Structure

Bolt CEP organizes code into distinct layers:

```
src/
├── js/                    # CEP JavaScript/Frontend
│   ├── main/             # Primary panel
│   │   ├── index.html
│   │   └── index.tsx     # React/Vue/Svelte entry
│   ├── settings/         # Secondary panel
│   ├── lib/              # Shared utilities
│   └── assets/
├── jsx/                  # ExtendScript code
│   ├── index.ts          # Main entry
│   └── [app]/           # App-specific modules
└── shared/              # Type definitions
```

Each panel operates as an independent page with shared code efficiency. The framework supports "a single JSX object attached to helper object $ for all your panels to prevent pollution in the global namespace."

## Core Configuration (cep.config.ts)

The TypeScript config file manages:

- **panels array**: Define UI panels with properties like `name`, `mainPath`, `panelDisplayName`
- **installModules[]**: Explicitly include Node.js packages
- **copyAssets[]**: Static files bypassing the bundler
- **copyZipAssets[]**: Assets bundled with ZXP distribution
- **parameters**: CEF browser flags (e.g., `--disable-site-isolation-trials`)
- **zxp.tsa**: Timestamping authority settings for code signing

## Build & Development Commands

| Command | Purpose |
|---------|---------|
| `yarn build` / `npm run build` | Compile & symlink to extensions folder |
| `yarn dev` / `npm run dev` | Hot-reload dev server (localhost:3000) |
| `yarn zxp` / `npm run zxp` | Package signed ZXP for distribution |
| `yarn zip` / `npm run zip` | Archive ZXP + sidecar assets |

## Key Features

- **Framework choices**: React, Vue, or Svelte for UI
- **Type-safe ExtendScript**: ES6 compiled to ES3 with `evalTS()` for bidirectional calls
- **Multi-panel support**: Easily add additional panels via config
- **Invisible panels**: Set `panelDisplayName: ""` for headless extensions
- **HMR**: Lightning-fast hot module replacement during development
- **GitHub Actions**: Pre-configured workflows for ZXP releases via git tags

## ExtendScript Organization

App-specific code splits by host application (e.g., `aeft.ts` for After Effects, `ilst.ts` for Illustrator) with "type-safe ExtendScript with Types-for-Adobe" integration.

content.content:
# Premiere Pro ExtendScript API Overview

Based on the documentation provided, here's what the guide covers:

## Core Objects Available
The guide documents key API objects organized by category:
- **Application level**: Application object for broad app control
- **Project management**: Project, ProjectItem, ProjectCollection objects
- **Sequences**: Sequence, Track, TrackItem objects for timeline manipulation
- **Metadata & Properties**: Marker, Metadata, Properties objects

## Key API Categories

The documentation is structured around several domains:

**General Objects** include encoder, production, and source monitor access, enabling you to control rendering and monitoring functions.

**Collections** provide access to multiple items—sequences, tracks, markers, and project items—allowing batch operations across project elements.

**Sequence Components** let you work with effects and parameters through Component and ComponentParam objects.

## Important Notice

The guide explicitly states: *"As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform."* ExtendScript remains supported through September 2026, but new development should target UXP instead.

## Navigation & Resources

The documentation recommends starting with the Overview section and reviewing the Changelog for API evolution. Contributors can access detailed guidance through the Documentation Contribution Guide.

**Note**: The provided content is an index/landing page, not detailed API documentation, so specific method signatures and event callbacks aren't included in this excerpt.

The guide explicitly states: *"As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP; Unified Extensibility Platform."* ExtendScript remains supported through September 2026, but new development should target UXP instead.

## Navigation & Resources

The documentation recommends starting with the Overview section and reviewing the Changelog for API evolution. Contributors can access detailed guidance through the Documentation Contribution Guide.

**Note**: The provided content is an index/landing page, not detailed API documentation, so specific method signatures and event callbacks aren't included in this excerpt.

- **General**: Encoder, Marker, Metadata, Production, Project, and SourceMonitor objects
- **Item**: ProjectItem and TrackItem objects
- **Sequence**: Component, ComponentParam, Sequence, and Track objects
- **Collections**: Multiple collection types for managing groups of objects

## 3) File Import and Timeline Manipulation

The provided content lacks specific examples of importing files or manipulating timelines. It references the PProPanel sample project as a practical resource but doesn't detail implementation steps.

## 4) Best Practices

The guide recommends using "Microsoft Visual Studio Code, with Adobe's ExtendScript debugging extension" rather than the outdated ExtendScript Toolkit for development work.

# CEP Resources: Version Compatibility & Documentation

## CEP Version Compatibility

The repository supports multiple CEP versions for Creative Cloud development:

- **CEP 12**: Latest version for current Creative Cloud applications
- **CEP 11**: Available for developing extensions in recent CC releases
- **CEP 10**: Supported for extensions across latest CC products
- **CEP 9**: Integrated with Creative Cloud 2019 applications
- **CEP 4-8**: Archived versions with legacy documentation

Each version includes compatibility tables documenting which Creative Cloud products support that CEP iteration.

## CSInterface.js Location

The documentation specifies that developers should "Include these files in your extension project if you need to use the APIs: CSInterface.js" and "Vulcan.js". However, the specific file path within the repository structure isn't explicitly detailed in the provided content. These files are housed within their respective CEP version directories (CEP_12.x, CEP_11.x, etc.).

## Manifest.xml Requirements

The provided content does not contain specific manifest.xml requirements or schema details. This information would be found in the detailed HTML Extension Cookbook documentation referenced in the repository.

## Version-Specific Documentation

Primary resources include:
- HTML Extension Cookbook (main reference guide)
- Version-specific cookbooks in each CEP directory
- ZXPSignCMD tool for packaging extensions
- Sample extensions repository for practical examples

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of the CSInterface evalScript callback and ExtendScript communication patterns:

## CSInterface evalScript Communication Pattern

### Basic Pattern

The HTML Panel communicates with Photoshop via evalScript. In the main.js you use `csInterface.evalScript('jsxFun()', callback)` where callback is a function defined somewhere (or anonymous).

### Asynchronous Nature

The default behavior shows that `csInterface.evalScript('app.documents.length', function(result) { numberOfDocuments = result; })` assigns the result to a variable, but an alert immediately after says "undefined" because of the asynchronous nature of evalScript - the interpreter goes ahead to the next line without waiting for the ExtendScript to return.

### Callback Function Structure

The evalScript function takes two params: the ExtendScript code to run, and a callback function which in turn takes as a param the returned value from the ExtendScript call.

### Handling the Async Issue

If the alert is moved within the callback it works properly. However, this can lead to the so-called "callback hell" – nesting evalScript calls one inside another.(no content)The callback is asynchronous so the second alert will not wait for the result from the callback. You need to use a promise.

### Passing Data Between JS and JSX

The panel's JS can send ExtendScript strings to the host application by means of the evalScript() function. On the other side, the host application can send strings back to the panel that the evalScript() second parameter callback is able to receive.(no content)If you need to pass complex parameters such as objects from your panel's JS to the host app's JSX, JSON.stringify() them first (no need to JSON.parse() them in the JSX – they arrive as objects). If you need to pass an object the other way around (from the host application JSX to the panel JS), you need to JSON.stringify() it in the JSX first, and JSON.parse() it in the JS.

### Passing Primitive Parameters

For primitive, multiple parameters this is easily done via CSInterface.evalScript() in the main.js: `csInterface.evalScript('sayHello("Ciao", 2014)')` and providing a corresponding function in the JSX file.

### Error Handling

In case of errors thrown on the JSX side, the returned value is always the "EvalScript error." string.

### Promise-Based Alternative

There's an interface for CEP panels to run Adobe ExtendScript evals and files (with arguments) as promises with cross-compatibility for AMD and node.js require. This can help avoid callback hell.

### Event-Based Communication (Alternative Pattern)

An alternative pattern uses CSXSEvent for communication. In the JSX you create a CSXSEvent object with a type and data, then dispatch it. In the JS you set up a listener using `csInterface.addEventListener()` to handle the event.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the CEP manifest.xml structure with ExtensionManifest, HostList, and RequiredRuntimeList:

## CEP manifest.xml Structure

The XML manifest must live at: `/CSXS/manifest.xml` (CSXS being the old name of CEP).

### Basic Structure

The manifest actually defines an extension bundle, which can include more than one extension - hence properties like `ExtensionBundleName` and `ExtensionList`.

### Key Components

**1. ExtensionManifest (Root Element)**

The root element contains bundle-level attributes. Here's an example from official Adobe samples:

```xml
<ExtensionManifest xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
    ExtensionBundleId="com.adobe.CEPHTMLTEST" 
    ExtensionBundleVersion="1.0" 
    Version="6.0">
```

**2. ExtensionList**

Contains multiple Extension elements defining different extension types like Panel1, Panel2, ModalDialog, and Modeless.

**3. HostList**

The entries in HostList refer to which Adobe tools the extension supports, using internal code strings and version numbers.(no content)You can use version ranges like `Version="[15.0,15.9]"` which will support Photoshop version 15.0 up to, and including, 15.9.(no content)If you use syntax with a parenthesis like `Version="[15.0,15.9)"`, you are supporting releases up to 15.9 but not including 15.9.

**4. RequiredRuntimeList**

Specifies the CEP runtime version required, for example: `<RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="5.0"/>`.

### Complete Example

Here's a structure example from an Adobe sample panel:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest Version="5.0" 
    ExtensionBundleId="com.adobe.PProPanel" 
    ExtensionBundleVersion="11.1" 
    ExtensionBundleName="Premiere Pro sample panel"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance">
    
    <ExtensionList>
        <Extension Id="com.adobe.PProPanel" Version="10.3.0" />
    </ExtensionList>
    
    <ExecutionEnvironment>
        <HostList>
            <Host Name="PPRO" Version="9.0" />
        </HostList>
        <LocaleList>
            <Locale Code="All" />
        </LocaleList>
        <RequiredRuntimeList>
            <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="6.0" />
        </RequiredRuntimeList>
    </ExecutionEnvironment>
    
    <DispatchInfoList>
        <!-- Extension UI configuration goes here -->
    </DispatchInfoList>
</ExtensionManifest>
```

### Host Application Codes

Common host codes include: DRWV (Dreamweaver), FLPR (Animate/Flash), IDSN (InDesign), AICY (InCopy), ILST (Illustrator), PHSP/PHXS (Photoshop), PPRO (Premiere Pro), PRLD (Prelude).

### Extension Types

You need to specify an extension's type in its manifest.xml. Available types include:

- **Panel** - behaves like any other application panel. It can be docked, participates in workspaces, has fly-out menus, and is re-opened at start-up if open at shutdown.
- **Modal Dialog** - opens a new extension window and forces the user to interact only with the extension window before returning control to the host application.
- **Modeless Dialog** - opens a new extension window but doesn't force the user to interact with the extension window. An Embedded Panel is the same as a Panel, but it cannot be undocked.
- **Custom (Invisible)** - for invisible extensions that remain hidden and never become visible during their whole life cycle.

For more detailed documentation, you can refer to the official [Adobe CEP Resources on GitHub](https://github.com/Adobe-CEP/CEP-Resources).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
# PProPanel manifest.xml Content

Based on the GitHub repository, here's the complete manifest structure for the Premiere Pro sample panel:

## Key Configuration Details

**Extension Bundle Information:**
- Bundle ID: `com.adobe.PProPanel`
- Bundle Version: `11.1`
- Extension Version: `10.3.0`
- Display Name: "Premiere Pro sample panel"

**Host Configuration:**
The extension targets "PPRO" (Premiere Pro) with version `9.0` and supports all locales.

**Runtime Requirements:**
CSXS runtime version `6.0` is required for execution.

**Resources:**
- Main interface: `./index.html`
- Script layer: `./PProPanel.jsx`

**CEF Command-Line Parameters:**
The panel runs with three security flags enabled—file access allowance, cross-file access permissions, and insecure content execution.

**UI Specifications:**
The panel operates as a dockable interface measuring 180 pixels wide by 300 pixels tall, appearing in the menu as "PProPanel (SDK sample panel)."

**Lifecycle Settings:**
The extension initializes as auto-visible, with commented sections suggesting optional event-based startup tied to application focus changes.

This manifest demonstrates Adobe's extension architecture for integrating custom functionality into creative applications through the Common Extensibility Platform (CEP) framework.
